children: Diminishing barometric pressure associated with an ascent to altitude reduces the amount of ambient oxygen available for gas exchange, a condition known as hypobaric hypoxia. Physiologic responses to hypobaric hypoxia mechanistically underlie many disorders collectively referred to as high-altitude illness

. Susceptibility to high-altitude illness is individualized and difficult to predict. Although high-altitude illnesses can occur at all ages regardless of fitness level, patients with a history of high-altitude–related illness are at risk for recurrence. Other risk factors include rapid ascent (more than 3500 m in less than 2 days or more than 500 m per day above altitudes of 3000 m) and medical comorbidities that impair oxygenation, such as interstitial lung disease, COPD, and pulmonary hypertension. Acetazolamide and gradual ascent to altitude can be used prophylactically in patients who have previously suffered high-altitude illness or have other risk factors.
Acetazolamide and gradual ascent to altitude can be used prophylactically in patients who have previously suffered high-altitude illness or have other risk factors.

Cerebral blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain are altered by the hypoxia and hypocapnia associated with the ascent to altitude. In acute mountain sickness—the most common high-altitude illness—symptoms are nonspecific and include headache, fatigue, nausea, and vomiting; disturbed sleep related to high-altitude periodic breathing is also common. Cerebral autoregulatory mechanisms can dampen the stress on blood flow, resulting in mild symptoms. Acute mountain sickness is estimated to affect as many as 25% of visitors to an altitude of 2000 m, the elevation at most major western U.S. ski areas. Heavy exertion and dehydration tend to amplify symptoms, which, provided there is no further ascent, typically resolve within 24 to 48 hours. Treatment and prevention approaches are shown in
In high-altitude periodic breathing, chemoreceptors that are sensitive to hypoxia increase ventilation. This drives arterial P
toward the apneic threshold and results in a pause in breathing (central apnea) when the threshold is crossed. With this pause, arterial P

eventually rises sufficiently to again stimulate breathing. The cycle of ventilatory overshoot, hypocapnia, and central apneas repeats at night. Patients complain of interrupted sleep and insomnia and may experience paroxysms of dyspnea that awaken them. Alcohol ingestion, which promotes dehydration, can intensify the sequelae of high-altitude periodic breathing.
Symptoms of acute mountain sickness are nonspecific and include headache, fatigue, nausea, and vomiting; disturbed sleep related to high-altitude periodic breathing is common.

When the cerebral compensatory pathways are overwhelmed, severe, life-threatening cerebral edema can ensue. High-altitude cerebral edema is a feared manifestation of acute mountain sickness that tends to occur at higher elevations (above 3000 m). Recognition of cerebral edema mandates immediate intervention. Definitive treatment is immediate descent from altitude, particularly when the patient is still ambulatory, because incapacitation at high altitude exponentially complicates evacuation.

Definitive treatment of high-altitude cerebral edema is immediate descent from altitude, particularly when the patient is still ambulatory, because incapacitation at high altitude exponentially complicates evacuation.

The pulmonary vasculature constricts in response to hypoxia, resulting in increases in pulmonary vascular resistance. An exaggerated increase in pulmonary artery pressure is associated with high-altitude pulmonary edema. High-altitude pulmonary edema is uncommon but can be life-threatening. Patients are often tachypneic and tachycardic, and crackles or wheezing can be heard on chest examination. Pink, frothy sputum or frank hemoptysis may occur, which heralds worsening gas exchange and respiratory failure. The treatment of choice is supplemental oxygen along with rest, both of which will acutely reduce pulmonary artery pressures. Descent from altitude should be considered. See

The principles of hypobaric hypoxia also apply to commercial airline travel. Cabins are pressurized to the equivalent of 1500 to 2500 m (approximately 5000-8000 ft) in altitude, resulting in an inspired oxygen tension between 110 and 120 mm Hg (about 70% of the levels encountered at sea level). The resultant arterial P
of approximately 60 mm Hg (8.0 kPa) is adequate for healthy individuals, but those with underlying pulmonary disease are at risk for significant hypoxemia during flight

The risk for pneumothorax in air travel is low, as airline cabins are pressurized. In patients with chronic lung disease (such as asthma or COPD), signs or symptoms indicative of a pneumothorax (acute chest pain, dyspnea) should prompt the in-flight administration of supplemental oxygen, which promotes resorption of pleural air. For patients with chronic lung disease associated with hypoxia, preflight evaluation to determine recommended oxygen use is helpful

After cardiothoracic surgery, a delay of 3 to 4 weeks before air travel is reasonable. An existing pneumothorax has traditionally been considered a contraindication to flight because of the potential risk for expansion and tension physiology. Air travel may be safe in the presence of a small postoperative pneumothorax that has been radiographically stable.

Pulse oximetry is a useful screening tool for patients who have chronic lung disease, with which an oxyhemoglobin saturation of less than 92% at sea level indicates a likely need for in-flight supplemental oxygen.
During air travel, doubling the flow rate is typically adequate for patients who are already receiving long-term supplemental oxygen.

Ahmedzai S, Balfour-Lynn IM, Bewick T, et al; British Thoracic Society Standards of Care Committee. Managing passengers with stable respiratory disease planning air travel: British Thoracic Society recommendations. Thorax. 2011;66 Suppl 1:i1-30.

Hu X, Cowl CT, Baqir M, et al. Air travel and pneumothorax. Chest. 2014;145:688-694.

Luks AM, Auerbach PS, Freer L, et al. Wilderness Medical Society clinical practice guidelines for the prevention and treatment of acute altitude illness: 2019 update. Wilderness Environ Med. 2019;30:S3-S18.
Luks AM, Swenson ER, Bärtsch P. Acute high-altitude sickness. Eur Respir Rev. 2017;26.
Meier D, Collet TH, Locatelli I, et al. Does this patient have acute mountain sickness?: the Rational Clinical Examination systematic review. JAMA. 2017;318:1810-1819.
Nicholson TT, Sznajder JI. Fitness to fly in patients with lung disease. Ann Am Thorac Soc. 2014;11:1614-22.

Nonspecific; include headache, malaise, anorexia, nausea, vomiting
Oxygen, acetazolamide, dexamethasone, descent from altitude, aspirin or NSAID for headache
Gradual ascent (<500 m/d) at high altitude; prophylaxis with acetazolamide or dexamethasone in rapid ascent or patients at high risk
Confusion, irritability, ataxic gait, coma, death
Descent from altitude, supplemental oxygen, hyperbaric therapy
Gradual ascent; consider acetazolamide or dexamethasone in patients at high risk
Cough, exertional intolerance, dyspnea at rest
(2-4 d after arrival at new altitude)
Supplemental oxygen and descent from altitude; adjunctive therapy: nifedipine, PDE-5 inhibitors
Gradual ascent; consider nifedipine in patients at high risk
